_meta.note: 5 detailed customer personas. Keto Kevin and Biohacker Ben have strongest VOC validation. Fasting Fiona and Weekend Warrior Will need further research.

archetypes.name: Keto Kevin
archetypes.lifestyle: Optimized daily routine. Tracks macros religiously. Listens to health podcasts. Active in keto communities online. Buys premium products when convinced of efficacy.
pain_points: Keto flu symptoms persist despite experience
LMNT is expensive for daily use
Wants a cleaner, less processed option
Wife thinks he spends too much on supplements
triggers: Sees a trusted keto influencer recommend a new electrolyte
Experiences renewed keto flu symptoms after a cheat day
LMNT raises prices or changes formula
Discovers marine plasma concept through podcast or Reddit
objections: Is this actually better than LMNT?
I already have a system that works
Another supplement brand making big claims
How do I know the sourcing is legit?
decision_drivers: Published research or third-party testing
Clean ingredient list (no fillers, no artificial)
Price-per-serving math vs current solution
Social proof from keto community members he trusts
archetypes.quote: I've optimized everything else in my diet - my electrolytes shouldn't be the weak link.

archetypes.name: CrossFit Claire
archetypes.diet: Paleo-ish. Not strict but avoids processed food. Prioritizes protein.
archetypes.lifestyle: Trains 4-6x/week. CrossFit box is her social life. Posts workouts on Instagram. Competitive but fun. Values performance and aesthetics equally.
pain_points: Gets cramps during WODs, especially in heat
Hates sugary sports drinks and their ingredients
Needs something gym-portable that fits in her bag
Wants a product that looks good on Instagram (aesthetic packaging)
triggers: Cramping during a competitive event or PR attempt
Seeing a fellow athlete post about an electrolyte product
Coach recommends electrolyte supplementation
Summer training intensifies dehydration symptoms
objections: I drink enough water already
Is this just another overpriced supplement?
I don't want to take something with weird ingredients
Does it actually taste good?
decision_drivers: Taste and mixability (non-negotiable)
Clean label she can feel good about
Endorsement from athletes or coaches she follows
Portable, gym-friendly packaging
archetypes.quote: I put so much effort into my workout - I'm not going to ruin it with some garbage electrolyte drink.

archetypes.name: Biohacker Ben
archetypes.diet: Experimental. Has tried keto, carnivore, paleo, now focuses on bioavailability and micronutrients.
archetypes.lifestyle: Tech or finance professional. Listens to Huberman, Attia, Rhonda Patrick. Wears Oura Ring or Whoop. Tracks HRV, sleep, glucose. Spends $200+/mo on supplements without blinking. Researches everything obsessively before buying.
pain_points: Wants THE BEST mineral source, not just adequate
Frustrated by incomplete synthetic mineral blends
Researches obsessively and can't find data on most brands
Skeptical of marketing claims without published evidence
triggers: Hears about marine plasma on a science-focused podcast
Reads a study on mineral bioavailability
Discovers his current electrolyte has undisclosed ingredients
Sees blood work showing mineral deficiencies
objections: Where's the research?
How is this different from Quinton?
Is the sourcing transparent and verified?
I need to see the full mineral profile and COA
decision_drivers: Published research or peer-reviewed data
Full transparency: COA, mineral profile, sourcing details
Bioavailability evidence (not just content claims)
Endorsement from scientists or MDs he respects
archetypes.quote: If it doesn't have published research behind it, I'm not putting it in my body.

archetypes.name: Fasting Fiona
archetypes.diet: Intermittent fasting, 16:8 or longer. May combine with low-carb or Mediterranean approach.
archetypes.lifestyle: Health-conscious professional or mother. Fasts for weight management, mental clarity, and longevity. Follows Dr. Mindy Pelz, Dr. Jason Fung. Active in fasting Facebook groups and subreddits.
pain_points: Feels terrible during fasting windows (headaches, dizziness, brain fog)
Worried that electrolytes will break her fast
Doesn't want sugar, sweeteners, or calories during fasting
Confused about what's actually safe to consume while fasting
triggers: Hits a wall during a longer fast (24h+) and feels awful
Reads that electrolyte depletion is the cause of fasting side effects
Sees a fasting influencer recommend a specific electrolyte
Starts extended fasting and needs a protocol
objections: Will this break my fast?
Why can't I just use salt?
I don't trust supplement companies
How is this different from the cheap stuff?
decision_drivers: Zero calories, zero sweeteners, zero insulin response
Endorsed by fasting community leaders
Clean, minimal ingredient list
Clear explanation of why it won't break a fast
archetypes.quote: I just want to feel good during my fast without worrying that I'm ruining it.

archetypes.name: Weekend Warrior Will
archetypes.diet: No specific diet. Tries to eat healthy but not obsessive. Drinks beer on weekends.
archetypes.lifestyle: Active but not obsessed. Plays weekend soccer, basketball, or does long hikes. Works a desk job. Not into the supplement scene. Values practicality over optimization. Shops at Costco.
pain_points: Gets cramps after weekend sports, especially as he ages
Doesn't want Gatorade (knows it's sugar water)
Not a supplement guy and doesn't want to become one
Wants something simple without a complicated protocol
triggers: Bad cramping episode after a weekend game
Buddy recommends something that's 'not like a supplement'
Sees a simple, no-BS ad that doesn't look like bro-science
Wife buys it for him after hearing about it
objections: I'm not a supplement bro
This is probably overpriced salt
I can just drink more water
I don't want to think about this stuff
decision_drivers: Simple: one product, easy to use, no protocol
Affordable (price-conscious, not premium-seeking)
Normal branding (not aggressive/masculine supplement aesthetic)
Recommendation from someone he trusts (not an influencer)
archetypes.quote: I don't want to become a supplement bro - I just want to stop cramping after basketball.
